chapterTitle: Net Present Value and Other Investment Criteria

columns.text: **9.2a** In this question, we are asked to define the payback period and and the payback period rule.

The time it takes for a corporation to return its investment costs is referred to as the **payback period**. The payback period guideline stipulates that a company should expect to repay its initial investment within a year. The payback period is the amount of time it takes for a company to recover the cost of an investment.
The **payback period rule** is a financial rule of thumb that suggests that a company should expect to recover its initial investment within a period of about 12 months.
**9.2b** This question invites us to share our ideas on what the payback period and accounting breakeven measure mean in relation to the payback period.

The payback period is an accounting break-even measure because **it measures when the cash inflows from an investment equal the cash outflows**. At this point, the investment has reached breakeven and the cash flow from the investment is equal to the cash flow from the original investment. This measure can be used to **compare different investments** since it is a simple way to calculate how long it will take for an investment to pay off. It is also important to note that the payback period may vary depending on the initial investment amount and other factors. Therefore, the **payback period is not always a useful measure when comparing investments.** However, it can be a useful tool for calculating how long it will take an initial investment to pay back its original cost.
